meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>make</kanji> a <kanji>task</kanji> you're looking for a certain <vocabulary>effect</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>action</vocabulary>. What task can you make right now to get the effect of learning more kanji?

A <kanji>public</kanji> <kanji>company</kanji> is a <vocabulary>government-run company</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>government-owned company</vocabulary>. In other words, it's a company that's run by national or local government in the interests of the public.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>build</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to build</vocabulary>.
You know that 建築 is architecture. So, someone of <kanji>house</kanji> <kanji>architecture</kanji> is someone who does architecture. They are an <vocabulary>architect</vocabulary>.
In the <kanji>present time</kanji> we <kanji>exist</kanji>. What time is it? It's <vocabulary>present</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>now</vocabulary>. It is the <vocabulary>current</vocabulary> time!

The kanji means <kanji>mix</kanji>, and you already learned its transitive and intransitive pair: 混ぜる (to mix) and 混ざる (to get mixed). 混じる is another intransitive verb, but it means <vocabulary>to be mixed in with</vocabulary>.

So how are 混ざる and 混じる different? 混ざる is used to talk about things that become mixed together as part of the same whole — like blended colors or intermingled groups. 混じる, on the other hand, is less about blending smoothly and more about something getting mixed in when it doesn't quite belong — static in your audio, scattered strands of gray in your dark hair, or even some random stranger sitting at your group's table.

You can remember this by thinking about how this out-of-place thing getting mixed in makes you want to <reading>jeer</reading> (じる): "Boo, get out of here! You don't fit in!"

You know that 主義 is "-ism." Add that ism to people who want to <kanji>protect</kanji> and <kanji>conserve</kanji> their country so it stays just the way it is (forever). That's <vocabulary>conservatism</vocabulary> and they're <vocabulary>conservative</vocabulary> people.

When people <kanji>evaluate</kanji> and <kanji>judge</kanji> you at every turn, it means you have quite a <vocabulary>reputation</vocabulary>, and indeed <vocabulary>fame</vocabulary>. Wouldn't this be terrible if people evaluated and judged you 24/7? Having that kind of reputation or fame would be difficult.

An <kanji>element</kanji> of <kanji>clear up</kanji> (like the sky clearing up!) is so <vocabulary>wonderful</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>splendid</vocabulary>. Sort of a weird word, but very useful. Just think of that wonderful feeling you get when the sun breaks and things clear up and it's awesome.

When something <kanji>escape</kanji>s from the <kanji>line</kanji> it should be on, that's a <vocabulary>derailment</vocabulary>.

脱線 can refer to train derailments (no surprise there), but often gets used figuratively to mean a <vocabulary>digression</vocabulary>, like in speech or writing. Do you ever derail conversations with your digressions?

You <kanji>escape</kanji> and <kanji>run</kanji> the hell out of there. Basically, you're trying <vocabulary>to escape</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to flee</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to break out</vocabulary>. Pretty simple.

脱走する specifically refers to escaping from a controlled or confined environment, like escaping from prison, a military base, or a guarded facility.
You're trying to <kanji>escape</kanji> from <kanji>tax</kanji>es? You scared of them? Huh? That's <vocabulary>tax evasion</vocabulary>, buddy. You're going to jail for that.

At  <kanji>each</kanji>  <kanji>station</kanji> someone keeps  <kanji>halt</kanji>ing the  <kanji>car </kanji>. What is this, a <vocabulary>local train</vocabulary>?! Yes, yes it is. You’re on a local train. People use it when they get on (or off) at the smaller stations.

If you’re not used to train travel, just remember that a "local train" is one that stops at every station on a line.
確認 is confirmation. When that's a verb, you have <vocabulary>to confirm</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to verify</vocabulary>.

Remember 済む and how it means "to come to an end." This is like that, but slightly different. This is <vocabulary>to finish something</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to settle something</vocabulary>, because this is when you're doing the coming to an end action. You can remember this because you're coming in to finish the score uno <reading>mas</reading> (ます) time. This is the last time.
経済 is economics. So, something that has to do with economics is the <vocabulary>economic</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>financial</vocabulary> situation.
There are member(s) of a committee (委員) all getting together to <kanji>meet</kanji>. This is the <vocabulary>committee</vocabulary> itself.
<kanji>Election</kanji> is 選挙 so when you make that word into a verb, you have <vocabulary>to elect</vocabulary>.

責任 is <kanji>responsibility</kanji>. If you add 感 you get a "feeling of responsibility." That's not really a thing people say. What people do say, however, is <vocabulary>sense of responsibility</vocabulary>. Do you have one?
This is where the <kanji>bus</kanji> (バス) halts. It's the <vocabulary>bus stop</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Halt</kanji> and <kanji>stop</kanji>. When something does this, it's in a <vocabulary>stoppage</vocabulary>.
When you <kanji>halt</kanji> <kanji>electricity</kanji> you experience a <vocabulary>power outage</vocabulary>. Makes sense. When the electricity stops you don't have any more power.
A <kanji>demon</kanji> that <kanji>suck</kanji>s <kanji>blood</kanji>? What mythological creature can you think of that sucks blood? How about a <vocabulary>vampire</vocabulary>? Them Sparklzzzz!

You <kanji>suck</kanji> something in and <kanji>obtain</kanji> it. Shhheewwwwww! When you suck something in and obtain it into your body, you have done <vocabulary>absorption</vocabulary> because it's been sucked inside of you.

I <kanji>obtain</kanji> some <kanji>territory</kanji>, so I want a <kanji>writte</kanji>n record of it. How will I get a written record of my obtained territory? How about with a <vocabulary>receipt</vocabulary>? Emailing one will do just fine.
Please <kanji>enter</kanji> what you've <kanji>obtain</kanji>ed in here. We'll divvy it all up later. But we have to enter it all here so we know our <vocabulary>income</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
<kanji>Leather</kanji>'s <kanji>fate</kanji> is in the hands of a <vocabulary>revolution</vocabulary>. It's the leather revolution! Off with these normal clothes and on with leather ones!
<kanji>Skin</kanji> <kanji>leather</kanji> is really just <vocabulary>leather</vocabulary> because leather is also skin. It's also <vocabulary>hides</vocabulary>.
When the status of your <kanji>employment</kanji> is "<kanji>nothing</kanji>" then you're probably <vocabulary>unemployed</vocabulary>. You're experiencing <vocabulary>unemployment</vocabulary>.

Your <kanji>employment</kanji> <kanji>location</kanji> is your <vocabulary>place of work</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>place of employment</vocabulary>. It's also your <vocabulary>workplace</vocabulary>.

Are you using WaniKani at your 職場 right now? Wouldn't that be funny.
Your <kanji>employment</kanji> <kanji>business</kanji> is your <vocabulary>occupation</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>profession</vocabulary>. What is your employment business?

The <kanji>employment</kanji> <kanji>member</kanji>s of a workplace are the <vocabulary>personnel</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>staff</vocabulary>. Pretty straightforward!

職員 and 社員 are two similar terms, but have different meanings. 社員 generally refers to employees of private companies, while 職員 refers to employees who work in various fields such as civil service, education, government, non-profits, and more.

To <kanji>have</kanji> <kanji>employment</kanji> just means <vocabulary>having a job</vocabulary>. Wow, congrats on <vocabulary>being employed</vocabulary>!

有職 is a formal word for saying that someone has a steady job, as opposed to 無職 (unemployed). You'll often see it in official writing like surveys or articles.
Ugh, time to <kanji>request</kanji> <kanji>employment</kanji> again. Time to go <vocabulary>job hunting</vocabulary>.

If you <kanji>quit</kanji> your place of <kanji>employment</kanji>, you are putting in your <vocabulary>resignation</vocabulary>, aka <vocabulary>resigning</vocabulary>.

辞職 is a formal term that refers to someone voluntarily leaving their job or post in professional settings.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

An <kanji>expert</kanji> who <kanji>watches over</kanji> and <kanji>defend</kanji>s people at all hours is the <vocabulary>nurse</vocabulary>. That's what nurses do, 24/7. They have to check up on people, defend their health, and watch over them, making sure they're okay. What a tough job.

A <kanji>samurai</kanji> who uses <kanji>speech</kanji> to <kanji>defend</kanji> people. This samurai does their battle in the court of law. This "samurai" is an <vocabulary>attorney</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>lawyer</vocabulary>.

To <kanji>preserve</kanji> and <kanji>defend</kanji> something is <vocabulary>to conserve</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to protect</vocabulary>. I won't let you destroy this land I'm trying <vocabulary>to protect</vocabulary>!

A <kanji>teach</kanji>ing <kanji>expert</kanji>/<kanji>teacher</kanji> is a <vocabulary>teacher</vocabulary>.

教師 is a relatively formal word for teachers. Unlike 先生, this word is specifically for people in the teaching profession and cannot be used as a name ender.
A <kanji>medicine</kanji> <kanji>expert</kanji> is someone who knows a lot about medicine. Those people are (I hope) generally <vocabulary>doctor</vocabulary>s.
Though there's no law about two kanji with the same meaning producing the same meaning, a <kanji>law</kanji> <kanji>law</kanji> is probably a <vocabulary>law</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>divide</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to divide</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to split something</vocabulary>.

It can also mean <vocabulary>to break something</vocabulary>, as in ワイングラスを割る (to break a wine glass). After all, you’re technically dividing the object into parts if you break it, right?
Let's <kanji>divide</kanji> the <kanji>duty</kanji> up amongst various people. Each person will have their own <vocabulary>role</vocabulary> in completing this duty.

<kanji>One</kanji> <kanji>division</kanji> is <vocabulary>ten percent</vocabulary>. You'll just have to imagine this in terms of tens going by. Must be some old Japanese percentage system that carried over or something. Just remember that one wari is ten percent, two waris are twenty percent, and so on.

When you <kanji>divide</kanji> something into parts and <kanji>join</kanji> them back together, you are better able to evaluate the <vocabulary>ratio</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>percentage</vocabulary> of these parts in relation to the whole. Think of all these parts, neatly separated and then placed next to one another. It's only because you divided them that you get to see them this way.

割合 usually refers to the ratio of a certain part when compared to the whole, often expressed as a percentage. When used this way it's similar to 比率, but 割合 is more common in everyday language.

Note that 割合 can also be used as an adverb, where it means <vocabulary>comparatively</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>fairly</vocabulary>.
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>judge</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to judge</vocabulary>.

You're going to get <kanji>judge</kanji>d times two. <kanji>Judge</kanji> and <kanji>judge</kanji> again. Once by the judge and another time by the jury. This is a whole <vocabulary>trial</vocabulary> here.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

In modern Japanese, this word is not commonly used as a standalone term. However, it is often found as part of proper nouns that refer to geographic locations that have a cape, as well as family names that are associated with capes.
This is one of those words that's easier to know if you jump to the reading first. Why? Because it's the name of a city. It's <vocabulary>Kawasaki</vocabulary>.
This word will be easier if you jump to the reading, since it's the name of a place, <vocabulary>Nagasaki</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>foundation</kanji> of your <kanji>standard</kanji> is where you place your <vocabulary>standard</vocabulary>. No more, no less. This foundation is where the standard is all based off of.

This word generally refers to a quantitative "standard" that’s a basis for evaluation.
An <kanji>anti</kanji> <kanji>rule</kanji> is when you break the rules. It's when you do a <vocabulary>foul</vocabulary>.

It's both a <kanji>law</kanji> and a <kanji>rule</kanji>. This usually refers to something that is a <vocabulary>physical law</vocabulary>, but also can simply be a <vocabulary>law</vocabulary>, too. Anyways, lots of rules. Lots of laws. It's both, so the stronger one (law) takes precedence.
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>provide</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to provide</vocabulary>.

When you follow standard procedure to provide what's needed, you make the perfect preparation! Both 準備 and 用意 mean "preparation," but the nuances are different. 準備 is about preparing in advance for an event or situation, often involving planning or setup. 用意 is about making sure specific items or resources are ready and available. For example, as part of the 準備 for a party, you might 用意 food and drinks for the guests. You could use 準備 for the food and drinks too — it would just emphasize that they're part of the overall event setup.
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>lead</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to lead</vocabulary>.

Take your <kanji>finger</kanji> and <kanji>lead</kanji> with it. Just point at things. Tell people where they need to go, what they need to do, all with your finger leading them. This is <vocabulary>guidance</vocabulary> you are providing.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

This is one of those words that makes more sense when you look at the reading first. Technically this is the "New Tree Trunk Line" but you wouldn't realize this is the Japanese <vocabulary>bullet train</vocabulary> aka <vocabulary>Shinkansen</vocabulary> from that, would you? Maybe going to the reading will help you after all.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>stretch</kanji>, and the verb version means <vocabulary>to stretch over something</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to spread out</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to be taut</vocabulary>, not to be confused with the type of stretching you do after a workout.

This word is both transitive and intransitive. When it follows を, it emphasizes the physical act of extending something over an area, like stretching a canvas over a frame, unfurling a sail on a ship, or roping off a crime scene. When following が, it expresses the resulting state of having been stretched or spread, like a bloated stomach, a swollen muscle, or a spider web.

This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>gentle</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>gentle</vocabulary> (but also <vocabulary>kind</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>warm hearted</vocabulary>).

A <kanji>man</kanji> who is <kanji>superior</kanji> to us is an <vocabulary>actor</vocabulary>, or more specifically a <vocabulary>male actor</vocabulary>.

Just a word of warning: over the years this word has taken on the connotation of "adult film actor" so most people would use 俳優 for "actor" now. You'll be learning that word very soon!
It was <kanji>superior</kanji> <kanji>previous</kanji>ly, so we need to go back there. That, amongst all the other things, is our highest <vocabulary>priority</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>superior</kanji> person <kanji>win</kanji>s. They will win the <vocabulary>championship</vocabulary> and be able to claim <vocabulary>victory</vocabulary> over all others.

Just like its kanji, this word means <vocabulary>house</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>home</vocabulary>. By extension, it also sometimes means <vocabulary>household</vocabulary>. It can go after someone’s name to say whose house it is, as in 山田宅 (Yamada’s house), and after words that give more information about the house, such as 女性宅 (women’s homes).
Your <kanji>self</kanji> <kanji>home</kanji> is your own home. It's <vocabulary>one's home</vocabulary>.
If you <kanji>dwell</kanji> in a <kanji>house</kanji>, that house is your <vocabulary>dwelling</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>residence</vocabulary>.
You live in the most <kanji>extravagant</kanji> of <kanji>swamp</kanji>s, which means you’re completely surrounded by <vocabulary>luxury</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>extravagant</vocabulary> things.

If you <kanji>carry out</kanji> something and <kanji>go</kanji>, the result is still <vocabulary>enforcement</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>carrying out</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>implementation</vocabulary> of whatever it is. There’s no point hanging around after you’ve enforced something! So you always carry out and go.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji means <kanji>appear</kanji>, so this word means <vocabulary>to appear</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to emerge</vocabulary>.

When you <kanji>express</kanji> something that's of the <kanji>present time</kanji>, you are saying something that only people of the current time understand. These are <vocabulary>expression</vocabulary>s or <vocabulary>figure of speech</vocabulary>. You say these things during the present time, not the future, not the past, the present time. Otherwise nobody would understand.
The <kanji>present</kanji> is the <kanji>truth</kanji>. It is what's going on right now. It is <vocabulary>reality</vocabulary>.

Your <kanji>present</kanji> <kanji>location</kanji> is the <vocabulary>on-site location</vocabulary>! And you're on the <vocabulary>scene</vocabulary> to check out what's currently going on.

現場 refers to an on-site location where something is happening or has happened. It can refer to a crime scene, an accident site, or a filming location. It may also refer to a construction site or a factory, as these are <vocabulary>workplace</vocabulary>s where more hands-on work or operations take place.
<kanji>Cow</kanji> <kanji>milk</kanji> is <vocabulary>cow's milk</vocabulary>, though most people just call cow's milk <vocabulary>milk</vocabulary>.

What is a <kanji>milk</kanji> <kanji>neck</kanji>? Think about where milk comes from. Now, think of what looks like a little neck on the thing that milk comes from. What is that thing? It's a <vocabulary>nipple</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>call</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to call</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to call out</vocabulary>. As in "HEY, YOU!"
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

A <kanji>superior</kanji> <kanji>haiku</kanji> requires someone really famous and well known to read it... it's just on that level. Who is super well known and who deserves to read this superior haiku? A great <vocabulary>actor</vocabulary>, perhaps?

A <kanji>haiku</kanji> <kanji>paragraph</kanji> is just a <vocabulary>haiku</vocabulary>. Haikus are little haiku paragraphs.

You will learn kanji
The Crabigator watches
He feeds on reviews
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>excel</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to excel</vocabulary>.

Something that's <kanji>superior</kanji> will <kanji>excel</kanji>. It is <vocabulary>superior</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>excellent</vocabulary> in every way.

This word is typically used to describe someone's superiority or excellence, often in comparison to others.
You know how 経済 is economics, right? Well, add <kanji>study</kanji> to that and you have the study of economics, aka <vocabulary>economics</vocabulary>.

The kanji means <kanji>raise</kanji>, and this verb is when you do that to something. It's transitive. So this means <vocabulary>to raise something</vocabulary>. It actually has a pretty wide meaning, and can also mean "raise" in the sense of <vocabulary>to cite something</vocabulary>, like an example. It can even mean <vocabulary>to hold something</vocabulary>, like an event.
批判 is <kanji>criticism</kanji> so the verb version of that would be <vocabulary>to criticize</vocabulary>.

Remember how 増える is "to increase" (as in, something just increases, you aren't doing the increasing yourself). This one is that one, where you're doing the increasing. So, this word means <vocabulary>to increase something</vocabulary>. You know you're doing the increasing because you said "yes" (やす) to increasing something, and did it yourself.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>cut off</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to cut off</vocabulary>.

This is often used metaphorically to describe cutting off things that tie us down mentally or societally. This includes ending bad habits, so it also means <vocabulary>to quit doing something</vocabulary>.

Don't confuse this with 断る which means "to refuse." You know this is to cut off because of the つ, which hints that you have had <reading>two</reading> (つ) too many chocolates, and it's time to cut you off.

Go ahead and <kanji>carry out</kanji> the task and <kanji>establish</kanji> the <vocabulary>institution</vocabulary>. To carry out and establish something is to institute it too. What do you institute? An institution.
When something happens with a <kanji>sudden</kanji> <kanji>nature</kanji>, it happens... <vocabulary>suddenly</vocabulary>.

The kanji is <kanji>descend</kanji>, but this verb vocab word is <vocabulary>to get off</vocabulary>, as in, to get off the train, or to get out of the car. If you think about trains back in the day, you had to descend down to the platform to get out of them, which is how this word became what it is. You know that this word is the "to get off" word because once you get off the train, you enter the <reading>real</reading> (りる) world, where hardships are real and not as comfy as the train.

Figuratively, this word also means <vocabulary>to step down</vocabulary>, as in "to give up" or "to resign” from something. For example, you can say ニュース番組を降りる (to step down from a news program) or ゲームを降りる (to drop out of a game).

A <kanji>renew</kanji> <kanji>clothes</kanji> <kanji>room</kanji> is a <vocabulary>changing room</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>locker room</vocabulary>.

更衣室 is a room where people change their clothes, commonly found in places like gyms, swimming pools, schools, or workplaces.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
A <kanji>book</kanji> <kanji>shelf</kanji> is a <vocabulary>bookcase</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>bookshelf</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>door</kanji> <kanji>shelf</kanji> is a shelf with a door on it. What kinds of shelves do you know of that have doors on them? How about <vocabulary>cabinet</vocabulary>s? Or maybe <vocabulary>cupboard</vocabulary>s?
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
A <kanji>purple</kanji> <kanji>color</kanji> is <vocabulary>purple</vocabulary>. Simple as that!
Your <kanji>performance</kanji> <kanji>skill</kanji> allows you to be great at <vocabulary>acting</vocabulary> and doing awesome <vocabulary>performance</vocabulary>s.
If 演 is <kanji>performance</kanji> then the verb version of this would be <vocabulary>to perform</vocabulary>.

When you turn <kanji>acting</kanji> into <kanji>art</kanji> you get the <vocabulary>performing arts</vocabulary>. It is <vocabulary>popular entertainment</vocabulary>! Lights, action! Welcome to Broadway!

This word is more traditional and isn't used very much these days.

What's <kanji>above</kanji> the stage and involves <kanji>acting</kanji>? A <vocabulary>performance</vocabulary>!

This word does not refer to an actor's acting on stage. Instead, it usually refers to a theatrical or musical presentation in its entirety, so it's used in contexts relating to the act of staging an artistic or dramatic production, or features of the production itself, like its start time or running time (as in 上演時間).

A <kanji>machine</kanji> that can quickly generate a <kanji>part of speech</kanji> is handy for remembering <vocabulary>one's lines</vocabulary> on stage. If you forget your <vocabulary>line</vocabulary>, just activate the machine, and it will give you a helpful prompt: "Adjective! Adjective!"

台詞 usually means a line or speech in a play, movie, or drama — something a character says out loud. But it's also used in everyday talk when someone makes a <vocabulary>remark</vocabulary> that's clever, dramatic, or memorable, almost like quoting a line.
Remember how you learned that 心得 means "knowledge"? Well the verb version of that is <vocabulary>to know</vocabulary>. (You know it deep in your heart.)

Remember how you learned that 埋める means "to bury?" Well this is something that is being buried, maybe even you! Either way, you're not the one doing the burying. It means <vocabulary>to be buried</vocabulary>.

埋まる can also mean to be filled, like a pond being completely filled by dirt from a landslide or seats being filled at an event.

You know that 主義 is "-ism." If you add that to being <kanji>comfort</kanji>able like you're in <kanji>heaven</kanji> then you have lots of <vocabulary>optimism</vocabulary>. You're sure you'll be okay in any situation!

This is a noun in Japanese but, depending on the context, it's often translated into English as an adjective.
<kanji>Swamp</kanji>s and <kanji>mountain</kanji>s happen <vocabulary>a lot</vocabulary> in Japan. That's why we use this to mean <vocabulary>many</vocabulary>! Because there are many of them!
The <kanji>present time</kanji> is the time you're <vocabulary>actually</vocabulary> in. You aren't <vocabulary>really</vocabulary> in any other time, because that's not how time works!
<kanji>Divide</kanji> and <kanji>calculate</kanji>? Why, that's just <vocabulary>division</vocabulary>!
This is a single kanji with hiragana that ends in an い, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>envy</kanji>? It's also <vocabulary>envious</vocabulary>!

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.

If you <kanji>obtain</kanji> something, you'll want it <vocabulary>to fit inside</vocabulary> your bag. Otherwise how can you take it home? When talking about problems or emotions, this verb can also mean <vocabulary>to settle down</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to be finished</vocabulary> like a dispute settling down or someone’s anger calming down.

Like most verbs with まる as okurigana, this is an intransitive verb. That means it happens by itself, with no emphasis on the person or thing that's making something fit inside, or settle down.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.

The kanji 加 means <kanji>add</kanji>, and this verb means <vocabulary>to be added to</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to join in</vocabulary>.

It is an intransitive verb, like most verbs ending in わる. That means that it happens by itself, or at least the cause of the adding is not you. Something gets added to something else, perhaps by magic?
You can guess this is an adjective from the い at the end. The meaning for the kanji is <kanji>itchy</kanji>, and the adjective version is <vocabulary>itchy</vocabulary> too.

You <kanji>exit</kanji> the building and <kanji>stretch</kanji> in preparation for your <vocabulary>business trip</vocabulary>. This is the routine you always follow for your business trips: exit, and stretch.
You already know that 町 means "town" and that 外れ can mean "periphery" or "outskirts." This is just a combination of the two, so it means the <vocabulary>outskirts of town</vocabulary>.

What <kanji>season</kanji>s should you keep an <kanji>eye</kanji> on? The seasons that are <vocabulary>turning point</vocabulary>s in your life. Keep an eye on those seasons, because you don't want to miss the <vocabulary>critical juncture</vocabulary>s and <vocabulary>milestone</vocabulary>s.

A <kanji>rain</kanji> <kanji>door</kanji> is really just a <vocabulary>shutter</vocabulary>. In Japan, having shutters for rain protection is very common. When there were no glass windows, the shutters were simply like exterior doors in Japan, so "rain door" kind of makes sense as "shutter"! 

This word is usually for <vocabulary>sliding storm shutter</vocabulary>s. For other types of shutters, you can just say シャッター.

The kanji means "come true" or <kanji>grant</kanji>, and this is the transitive verb version of that, making this <vocabulary>to grant</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to fulfill</vocabulary>.

叶える refers to making something desired come true, either for oneself or someone else. It's usually used in the context of fulfilling wishes, dreams, or goals, but it can also be used for granting someone's request in more formal contexts.

The kanji <kanji>self</kanji> is all by itself! So, naturally, this word means <vocabulary>oneself</vocabulary>. Don't let the ら on the end confuse you, by the way — this word is singular.

Like 自分, 自ら means "oneself," but it's mostly used in formal or literary contexts. It can also be used as an adverb to mean <vocabulary>on one's own initiative</vocabulary> to emphasize voluntary action, or <vocabulary>personally</vocabulary> to highlight direct involvement — for example, 自ら辞める (to quit on one's own initiative) or 自ら謝る (to personally apologize).
